text:
It’s true that doing less can be harder. 

This applies in art and in life. 

Every word, every scene, every activity must count for more. 

An editor is ruthless in making every word count. 

Instead of saying it in two sentences, can you say it in one? 

Is it possible to use one word where two are used? 

Alan D. Williams observed two basic questions for the author. 

Are you saying what you want to say? 

Are you saying it as clearly and concisely as possible? 

Condensing means saying it as clearly and concisely as possible. 

In life, condensing allows us to do more with less. 

For example, Graham Hill moved into a 420-square-foot apartment. 

He wanted to see how well he could condense everything he owned. 

The ultimate result was a design he calls a “little jewel box.” 

The jewel box works because every piece of furniture has multiple functions. 

The wall on the left acts as a large projector screen. 

It also houses two guest beds for visitors. 

The wall to the right folds down over the couch. 

It reveals a queen bed. 

Everything does double or triple duty. 

In other words, everything makes a greater contribution. 

This design was so innovative he made it a business. 

He named it, appropriately, LifeEdited.com. 

But to be clear, condensing doesn’t mean doing more at once. 

It simply means less waste. 

It means lowering the ratio of words to ideas. 

It also means lowering square feet to usefulness. 

It means lowering effort to results. 

To apply condensing to our lives, we need to shift the ratio. 

We need to shift activity to meaning. 

We need to eliminate multiple meaningless activities. 

We should replace them with one very meaningful activity. 

For example, one employee routinely skipped the weekly meeting. 

He asked others what he had missed. 

Thus, he condensed a two-hour meeting into ten minutes. 

He invested the redeemed time getting important work done. 

An editor’s job is not just to cut or condense. 

It is also to make something better.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Condensing in both editing and life involves eliminating waste to enhance clarity and meaning, allowing for greater contributions with less effort.
